alt_statements.statement: I think the people in charge at colleges should make sure everyone is safe and not let anyone hurt or bully other people, even if they disagree about Israel and Gaza. They should remind students to be kind and listen to each other, because it’s important to care about people’s feelings and remember that God wants us to love our neighbors.

I think university administrators should let students protest and speak up about Israel and Gaza as long as it stays peaceful and nobody is being bullied or threatened. They should make sure everyone feels safe, no matter what side they’re on, and maybe set up talks or forums where people can listen to each other and learn the facts instead of just yelling. Since I believe in fairness and kindness, I think it’s important they stop real hate or violence but still respect people’s right to care and express their beliefs.

As someone who believes in social justice and has seen people at their most vulnerable during my years in nursing, I think university administrators must protect students’ rights to protest and speak out on Israel and Gaza, while enforcing clear, consistent rules against harassment, threats, and discrimination of any kind. They should create structured spaces for dialogue, provide support for students who feel unsafe or targeted, and resist pressure—whether from politicians or donors—to silence peaceful political expression.

As someone who values free expression and comes from a community that’s seen its share of struggle, I think campus administrators should protect students’ right to protest while making sure everyone is physically safe and no group is harassed or dehumanized. They shouldn’t crack down just because views are controversial or make donors and politicians uncomfortable, but they should draw a firm line at hate speech, threats, and blocking other students’ ability to learn.

University leaders should allow peaceful demonstrations and free speech, but they must set clear rules so protests do not turn into violence, harassment, or disruption of classes. Having seen conflict and hardship in my own life, I believe they should protect every student’s safety first, treat all sides fairly, and keep politics from overshadowing the university’s main job: education and helping young people build a better future.

As someone who worked hard to build a better life for my family and believes in equal opportunity, I think university administrators need to protect both free speech and student safety without taking sides politically. Peaceful demonstrations about Israel and Gaza should be allowed, but clear rules must prevent harassment, threats, or blocking other students from learning. Campuses should also encourage respectful dialogue and education, so students actually listen to each other instead of just yelling across a line.

As someone who works in a hospital and sees the importance of safety, I think university administrators need to protect students’ rights to peaceful protest while drawing very clear lines against harassment, intimidation, or disruption of learning. They should create structured, transparent guidelines that apply equally to all groups, and facilitate dialogue that includes Jewish, Palestinian, and other affected students rather than taking a partisan stance. Administrators also have a duty of care: they should proactively provide counseling and support services for students who feel threatened or traumatized, and enforce policies consistently so campuses remain both open to dissent and fundamentally safe.

As a Jewish medical research scientist, I care deeply about both free inquiry and the safety and dignity of everyone on campus. University administrators should protect robust, even passionate, political expression about Israel and Gaza while drawing a clear, consistently enforced line against harassment, dehumanizing rhetoric, and disruptions that shut down teaching or research. They should respond with transparent policies grounded in evidence, civil rights law, and data on campus safety—not political pressure—while investing in facilitated dialogue and support services for students most directly affected.

As someone who has spent her life in the arts, I believe university administrators should protect peaceful protest as a vital form of expression while firmly preventing harassment, violence, and discrimination against any group—Jewish, Muslim, Palestinian, Israeli, or otherwise. They should create structured forums for dialogue, teach historical context, and listen closely to students on all sides, rather than rushing to criminalize or silence them. Balancing safety with free speech is hard, but it’s precisely in painful, polarizing moments like Israel/Gaza that universities must model empathy, critical thinking, and respect for human dignity.

As someone who believes in both personal freedom and justice, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to peaceful protest while enforcing clear, content-neutral rules that keep everyone safe. They should actively discourage harassment, threats, and disruption of learning, but not shut down demonstrations simply because they’re controversial or uncomfortable. Administrators also have a responsibility to foster real dialogue—bringing in diverse speakers, facilitating structured discussions, and making sure Jewish, Muslim, Israeli, Palestinian, and all other students feel physically safe and respected on campus.

Universities need to protect free speech, but they also have a duty to maintain order and safeguard every student’s physical safety and ability to learn. I think administrators should clearly define and enforce neutral rules: peaceful protest is allowed, but harassment, intimidation, disruptions of classes, or support for terrorism should trigger firm consequences. Campus policies should be applied consistently to all groups, without political favoritism, while making sure Jewish and Muslim students in particular feel secure and respected. In a country built on both liberty and the rule of law, universities shouldn’t be training grounds for mob rule.

As someone who values both order and fairness, I think university administrators should protect students’ rights to peaceful protest while enforcing clear, consistently applied rules about safety, harassment, and disruption of classes. On something as charged as Israel/Gaza, they need to stay neutral in official capacities, make sure all sides can speak without intimidation, and step in firmly if demonstrations turn into targeting individuals or groups.
